title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with technical, media, communications, or marketing background will be assigned to the office. Additionally, individuals will be appointed within various components and offices of the Department to support the efforts. The Science and Technology Directorate appoints an individual as a liaison to the Office for Countering Violent Extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism is responsible for coordinating activities to counter violent extremism, identifying risk factors, populations targeted by extremist propaganda, and managing outreach to at-risk communities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism is responsible for coordinating activities to counter violent extremism, including developing a Department-wide strategy guiding policies and programs. This strategy addresses counter-messaging programs, leveraging technology and social media platforms, and learning from other partners engaged in similar activities. The Department's activities related to countering violent extremism include engagement, outreach, cooperative agreements with various agencies, ensuring respect for privacy and civil liberties, and developing metrics to evaluate programs. Additionally, new research and analysis requirements are identified in consultation with the Under Secretary for Science and Technology. The Department is focused on countering violent extremism through engagement, outreach, and developing metrics. This includes disseminating information to practitioners and assessing extremist propaganda methods. Additionally, a counter-messaging program is being established to craft strategic messages using technology and available resources. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates activities with other agencies, represents the Department internationally, provides guidance on grant usage, and administers grant programs in collaboration with FEMA. A memorandum of understanding is established with FEMA. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, establishes a grant program for community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. The Department will provide an implementation plan for the grant program, including eligibility and application criteria, methodology for awarding grants, and monitoring procedures. Community groups funding violent extremist activities are ineligible for grants. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit annual reports to Congress for the next five fiscal years. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism will submit annual reports to Congress detailing the Department's programs, budget, staff, cooperation with other agencies, outcome-based metrics for program evaluation, and steps taken to assess program success. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism will provide Congress with detailed summaries of outreach efforts, grants awarded, training programs, personnel and funding needs, adaptation to threat environment, protection of civil rights and liberties, evaluation of grant program effectiveness, and incorporation of lessons learned from previous programs. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism will learn from other departments and agencies, as well as governments and communities. It defines violent extremism as ideologically motivated terrorist activities. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Office for each fiscal year from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 for the grant program. This section will terminate five years after enactment.
